text: at chimpanzee sanctuary Northwest we
have six females and one male we have
got Jodi Jaimie Annie
Missy foxy burrito and negra when I came
to chimpanzee sanctuary Northwest I
formed bonds with each of the
chimpanzees but there was something that
stood out to me with Jodi and I think it
had something to do with looking into
her eyes and seeing the mess of windows
of her soul
I felt something very deep something
that really connected me to her and I
realized at that moment that there were
so many other Jodi's that had this
sorrowful and really touching story and
they all need the opportunity to come to
sanctuary the seven chimpanzees at
chimpanzee sanctuary Northwest came to
the sanctuary in 2008 they were
previously used in hepatitis vaccine
research at a private lab in
Pennsylvania and Jodi in particular was
also used as a breeder she would give
birth they would take her baby away from
her within 24 hours to then be used in
biomedical research so that cycle just
continued year after year after year
I think Jodi has had the biggest
transformation she was very pale very
little hair very distrustful of humans -
now being this beautiful female
chimpanzee that likes to interact with
others who is engaged is very nurturing
and is amazing to see it really is a
testimony to forgiveness I really think
that chimpanzees have taught me
personally a lot about forgiveness
now she likes to spend her days relaxing
and building nests which shows just how
comfortable she is in her setting so
this is just another sign that we're
successfully simulating things in the
wild at the sanctuary the chimpanzee
still like a lot of human interaction
and we do that safely and from a
distance but they still like to have
play chase and knuckle rubs which will
rub the knuckle against the back of the
chimpanzee through the mesh and just do
a little interactions they still like
that you know engagement so to speak we
serve a variety of fruits and vegetables
and we try to limit primate chow as much
as possible
Missy uh uh do you want a sweet potato
we want to give just as much of a
variety because each chimpanzee has
their favorites and dislikes and so we
want to make sure that we're
accommodating everybody's favorites as
much as possible but we also want to
make sure that they're getting a
well-balanced nutritious diet and one
more there you go another big milestone
in the movement was seeing that the
National Institutes of Health announcing
that they are going to retire most of
their chimpanzees over the coming years
as well as US Fish and Wildlife Service
announcing that she could stop split
listing the chimpanzees and now listed
as endangered species rather than
threatened species and this is a great
moment in history where we're educating
the public and inspiring people to make
that difference and I'm really
encouraged and hopeful that by all of
this we will see some other Dian Fossey
Xin Jane Goodall is coming up and making
huge differences in the lives of
chimpanzees
